dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Whispering of nuns at prayer.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Nuns at prayer; MOTHER MIRIAM, the Superior closes the ga it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The nuns walking around the courtyard in an anticlockwise saying the rosary.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A line of nuns kneeling at prayer. Closeups of various in

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A single shot of the building.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: SISTER MARGUERITE is locking up for the night, shutting d turning off lights, finally walks off down the corridor. terrified scream is heard, the voice of a young woman.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Lights in the windows flick on.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The nuns    are running up the corridor in their night dr calling    urgently in French. They reach the door of Sis and try    the door. It is blocked. Pushing harder they s stained    figure of SISTER AGNES. Much alarm and crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes!... Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: An ambulance comes tearing down the road, siren blaring. siren and stops outside the convent gates. The nuns open the ambulance drives inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Two PARAMEDICS urgently run the stretcher down the hall t unconscious figure of Sister Agnes. The Mother Superior d wipes and kisses her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to put something here to stop the bleeding. Excuse me Sister. She'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lift her on to the stretcher and run back down the h The Mother Superior looks around worriedly and goes into.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: She kneels down by a waste paper basket full of bloodied starts to pull them out. Then she freezes, makes the sign cross and starts to weep.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: An aerial shot of the great cross of Montreal. Superimpos are the words "MONTREAL, QUEBEC".

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A normal busy day. A car pulls up with a woman and a man woman is MARTHA LIVINGSTON. She kisses the man (LARRY), g the car, runs across the road dodgingtraffic and goes up the courthouse. There a group of REPORTERS there and a su of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they are now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha watches intently as 3 nuns, the Mother Superior, S Marguerite, and Sister Agnes (dressed in a white novices their LAWYER come out of the court escorted by police. Th leap on them, taking photographs, asking questions in Eng French. Suddenly Sister Agnes looks right at Martha, then quickly bustled past. Martha goes on into the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Inside EVE, LYON, and JUSTICE LEVEAU are sitting. Martha by the window smoking furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha, it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Roger? He's free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is meet with her once or twice... then tell the court she's insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you dictating my position to me? We're getting into some sticky legal territories here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha, all we're saying is, no-one wants this to come to trial, not the Church, not the Crown... least of all me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve, she strangled a baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is interested in sending a nun to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not telling you what to decide Martha. We're not even telling you to take this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any reason why you feel you shouldn't take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha pauses for a long moment at the window, then turns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today's my birthday. I always make bad decisions on my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge, Eve and Lyon all chuckle. The Judge throws the on his desk towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha unlocks the door and comes in. She plays her answerphone and moves over to her cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answerphone whirs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, it's Helen, calling to tell you that Mrs Davenport phoned to confirm her appointment at nine o'clock tomorrow, okay? Bye bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some whirs and clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Martha,    it's Roger. Can you call me at the    hospital. I'd like your opinion on a case.    Oh, bye the way, happy birthday.    Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Marty it's Helen again. I cancelled your Wednesday afternoon appointment so you can visit with your mother. Bye bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) ???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha picks up a news paper with a photo of Sister Agnes the front.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Martha pulls up in her BMW outside the convent walls and out, cigarette in hand. A sign tangled over with creeper reads "Les Peti Soeurs de Marie Madeleine". Martha jangles a bell. After presses a buzzer. A   peephole in the door slams open and Marguerite looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonjour, I'm Doctor Martha Livingston, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peephole slams shut, but the door does open. Sister Marguerite glares at her. MARTHA (Cont.) Hello... I'm Doctor Martha Living...ston... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha realizes it is the cigarette that is causing the trouble and hastily     grinds it underfoot. MARTHA (Cont.) Excuse me... I'm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Marguerite eyes flick down at cigarette butt. Mart awkwardly tries to kick it away. MARTHA (Cont.) ...the court-appointed psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Marguerite gives a frosty imitation of a smile and motions for her to    come in. MARTHA (Cont.) Thank you. I um... I believe your Mother Superior's expecting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha and the Sister walk up the drive to the convent.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha follows Sister Marguerite into a grilled waiting r Sister moves    off, leaving Martha looking around curiou the MOTHER MIRIAM arrives from behind the grilled door, s Martha, sighs exasperatedly and enters giving Martha a sl start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming at her own little joke) Doctor Livingston I presume? I'm Mother Miriam Ruth. You needn't call Mother if you don't wish. (shaking hands) Most people find it uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carrying right on) I'm afraid the word brings up the most unpleasant connatations in this day and age...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call me Sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have tons of questions. You may smoke if you want to. Just don't tell any of the Sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha sits;   Mother Miriam gets her a box of matches. MOTHER MIRIAM (Cont.) They wouldn't understand, especially Sister Marguerite. She'd scare the pants off Queen Elizabeth. (she lights Martha's cigarette) Besides, I miss them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a smoker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two packs a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can beat that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfiltered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha inclines her head impressed. Mother Miriam sits do next to her. MOTHER MIRIAM (Cont.) Well, you have questions. (checks her watch) Fire away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knew about Agnes' pregnancy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she hide it from the other nuns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She undressed alone... she bathed alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she hide it during the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating her habit) She could have hidden a machine gun in here if she had wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't she have any physical examinations in this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're examined once a year. Her pregnancy fell in between the doctor's visits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't a clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man had access to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None as far as I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there a priest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Martineau, but I don't see him as a candidate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could there have been anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause) Obviously there was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you didn't try to find out who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) Believe me, I've done everything possible short of asking Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why haven't you asked her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam removes a tray from under a pot plant and brings it back to use as an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting again) She can't even remember the birth. Do you think she'd admit to the conception?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, someone gave her the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but that was some    ten months ago. I fail to see that the    identity of that somebody has anything    to do with this trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me those questions dear, I'm not the patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm the doctor. I'm the one who's going to decide what is, or is not important here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look doctor, I don't know how to tell you this politely, but I don't approve of you. Not you personally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The science of psychiatry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) Exactly. I want you do deal with Agnes as speedily and as easily as possible. She won't hold up under any sort of cross examination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also standing) I am not with the Inquisition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I am not from the Middle Ages. I know what you are! I don't want that mind cut open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Mother Miriam walks out.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A little later, Martha is sitting alone smoking. SISTER A enters and indicates that Martha should follow her. They the grilled room and head up a steep flight of wooden stairs. Faintly the voice of a single young woman can be heard singing in Latin.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha follows Sister Anne down the hall towards the sing They stop outside Agnes' room. Martha looks to see...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: ... Agnes an almost childlike young woman singing happily looking out the window. Then Agnes hears a slight sound and stops abruptl She turns to see Martha standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. I'm Doctor Livingston. I've been asked to talk to you. May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha moves further in the room. An ELDERLY NUN hovers outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a lovely voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it Sister Marguerite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes laughs and Martha closes the door, shutting out the nun. MARTHA (Cont.) You're very pretty Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't anyone ever told you that before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything... may I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They both sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First thing that comes to your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God!    But there's nothing to say about God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second thing that comes to your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever loved anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who in particular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, have you ever loved another man... other than, Jesus Christ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there are so many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well do you love... do you love Father Martineau?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he loves you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But... when I look into his eyes, I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been alone together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least once a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you meet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the confessional. A slightly awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, do ever see Father Martineau outside the... Agnes suddenly looks exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to talk about the baby don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw any baby... I think they made it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the night they said it came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were you sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something I ate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down... there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got sicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fell asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: In the middle of all the pain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Where did the baby come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What baby?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: The baby they made up.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: From their heads...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is that where they say it came from... ?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No, they say it came from the waste paper basket!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Where'd it come from before that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From God.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: After God... before the waste-paper basket.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I... I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Agnes, how are babies born?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes I do,    but I want you to...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (very agitated) I don't understand what you're talking about... you want to talk about the baby... everybody wants to talk about    the baby but... I never saw the    baby so I can't talk about the baby    because... I don't believe in the    baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's talk about something else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) No... no, I'm tired of talking, I've been talking for weeks, nobody believes me when I tell them anything... nobody listens to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also standing) Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens the door) No... no, I don't want to answer any more questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to ask them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing in the doorway) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that... you ask and I'll answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Anything.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The elderly nun looks out the window into the courtyard w Martha and Agnes are walking, then pulls the curtain acro

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Martha and Agnes are walking together. Martha is smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your real name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha Louise Livingston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at the moment, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't have them any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause) I've stopped menstruating

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoking is an    obsession with me. Maybe one day    I'll become obsessed with something    else, then I'll stop smoking... Do    you have any more questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think babies come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their mothers and fathers of course. Before that, I... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I think they come from... angel lights on their mothers chest and whispers into her ear. That makes good babies start to grow. And bad babies come from when a fallen angel squeezes in down there, and they start to grow, grow, till they come out down there. I don't know where good babies come out. And you can't tell the difference... except bad babies cry a lot... and they make their fathers go away... and their mothers get very ill... die sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sits down on a bench and Martha follows her. AGNES (Cont.) Mummy wasn't very happy when she died ... and, I think she went to hell because every time I see her she looks like she just stepped out of a hot shower, and I... I'm never sure if it's her, or the Lady who tells me things! They fight over me all the time. (staring into space) The Lady... I saw when I was ten. I was lying on the grass, looking at the sun, and the sun became a cloud, and the cloud became, a Lady. And she told me she would talk to me. And then... her feet began to bleed and I saw there... there were holes in her hands and in her side. And I tried to catch the blood as it fell from the sky, but I couldn't see any more because my eyes hurt because there were big black spots in front of them. And she tells me things like, like... right now she's crying Marie! Marie! ... but I don't know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha stands up, disturbed. Agnes is slightly delirious happiness. AGNES (Cont.) ... and... she uses me to sing, it's as if she's throwing a big hook through the air and it catches me under my ribs and tries to pull me up, and I... I can't move because Mommy's holding my feet and all I can do is sing in her voice... it's the Lady's voice, God loves you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And her cry echoes all around and the doves fly out of th bell tower. AGNES (Cont.) (to Martha) God loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know a Marie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam is standing checking some papers when Marth enters. Mother Miriam seems to have entirely regained her humour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... what do you think? Is she totally bananas or merely slightly off centre... or maybe she's perfectly sane and just a very good liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe Agnes is different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From other nuns... (laughs) Yes I... I've noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From other people! (moving across the room) I believe she is not crazy, nor is she lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could she have a baby and know nothing of sex or birth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's an innocent. She's a slate that's hasn't been touched except by God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lights a cigarette) That's ridiculous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves to her desk, starts writing) In her case it isn't. She's had very little schooling. Her mother kept her home almost all the time and when her mother died Agnes came here, to us. She's never been out there Doctor. She's never seen a movie or a television show. She's never even read a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she's so innocent, how come she murdered a child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't! This is manslaughter, not murder. She didn't consciously kill that baby. She'd lost a lot of blood. She was unconscious by the time we got to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, someone else could have done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... not in the eyes of the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already told you what I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That she was unconscious, yes! So someone easily could have come in the room and killed the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really believe something like that happened do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the other nuns found out about the baby and... and wanted to avoid a scandal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam removes the tray from under a pot plant and bangs it down in front of Martha to act as an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's absurd!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That possibility never occurred to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-one knew about Agnes' pregnancy. No-one. Not even Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Martha's car exits out of the convent and heads up the ro

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The car radio is playing light band music...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been listening to Mostly Music from Montreal. This is CBC Radio. (and again in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha flicks the radio off and stops the car. She thinks a moment then...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ... she turns the car around and heads back in the direct she came.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Martha drives in through an entrance and pulls up outside presbytery.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: From inside the house, Martha can be seen knocking on the glass fronted door.     Presently a huge, fat HOUSEKEEPER answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Father Martineau in please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answers in French) ???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The housekeeper indicates she should enter and walks back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (halting briefly) Wipe your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move into the next room. The housekeeper goes furthe calling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pere Martineau... (in French) ???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha stands uncertainly at the doorway. The sound of thumping is heard, and then the figure of a very old priest, FATHER MARTINEA appears walking with a stick.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Father Martineau and Martha are having tea. He pours a sl of whisky from a   flask into her cup and an even larger slu own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (French accent) They arise at five in the morning... and they're in bed by nine at night. Even if a man could get to them, he would probably find them praying. That's why I see that the real question is not only how he got in, but when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're the only man to see them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you Doctor, even if I had the inclination, how could I possibly catch her? She would have to be a very slow and patient nun. (they both laugh) Ah no... they're a very special and rare people those Sisters. Only a few of them left in this modern world, consecrated to the praise of God.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: An elderly WOMAN is sitting watching "Spiderman" on TV cackling with laughter. She is physically alright, but quite senil enters, goes over to her and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mama (pulls up a chair) ... brought you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, I'm trying to watch this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your favourite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Martha, Mama. (hands over a tub of icecream) There you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie brings me icecream too you know. Chocolate... my favourite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought cherry-vanilla was your favourite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any more... now I like chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stroking her hair) Did you have a good week Mama. Are they treating you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Martha never comes to see me. You watch it, she's going straight to hell... after all the things she said to me. Then she marries that son of a bitch of a Frenchman... has an abortion. I knew that one wouldn't work out. Not like you Marie. You got married to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting up) Marie's dead Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when you    was a little girl Marie. You come back    from the movies and you'd say - Mama    that ending was so sad... and I'd tell    you they had all the happy endings locked    away in a vault in Hollywood. (chuckles) And you believed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, that wasn't Marie, that was me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long pause) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I'm Martha, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It is raining... distant thunder in the background. Marth standing under an umbrella talking to Sister Anne who is feeding the chickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convent was built for over fifty. Not many of us left... just us and the chickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you survive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we own the land around here. But we rent it out. We keep a few acres for ourselves, (indicating) some wheat, corn, some vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's a lot of land. You must have help. Do you have field hands that help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We work the land alone. No-one but Sister Marguerite and I are permitted contact with the public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Anne, which was Agnes' room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Anne points up to a window on the corner of the convent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that one there, in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one up on the third floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam unlocks a padlock on the door, opens it for Martha. They both      enter the room which is totally pl stripped of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This convent is locked solid. The only one that has a key is Sister Marguerite and she wouldn't let Christ in after dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's been known to happen in the day too. Maybe Agnes went to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, you've talked to her. She doesn't even know how babies are born, let alone made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you first learn about her... innocence, the way she thinks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly after she came to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you weren't shocked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was appalled, just as you are now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stopped eating completely...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: In flashback:   Agnes, all in white is lying face down in sign of the cross in front of the altar. Mother Miriam enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was before her pregnancy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About two years before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam stops in front of Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, it has come to my attention that you have stopped eating. Why is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) I've been commanded by God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) He talked to you Himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd punish me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the other Sisters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam glances up at an older NUN who has been in chapel watching all along. She takes the hint and hobbles MOTHER MIRIAM (Cont.) Why would she tell you to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Agnes look at me.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (looking up) Because I'm getting fat.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Oh, for Heaven's sake.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I am, there's too much flesh on me.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'm a blimp.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Why does it matter whether you're fat or not...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Because...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: ... You needn't worry about being attractive here.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I do, I have to be attractive to God.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: He loves you the way you are.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No he doesn't. He hates fat people.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Who told you this?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It's a sin to be fat.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Look at the statues, they're thin.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That's because they're suffering... suffering is beautiful, I want to be beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who tells you these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ said it in the Bible, he said - suffer the little children, I want to suffer like a little child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely distressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what he meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...    I am a little child but my body keeps    getting bigger and soon I... I won't    be able to fit in, I... I won't be able    to squeeze into Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes dear, Heaven is not a place where... Agnes gets to her knees and pushes up her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I mean... I mean look at these. I've got to lose weight, I'm a blimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my dear child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God blew up the Hindenburg. He'll blow me up, that's what she said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy I'll get bigger and bigger every day and then I'll pop but... but if I stay little it won't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother tells you this?... Agnes your mother is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she watches... she listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense, I'm your mother now and I want you to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to eat something Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't... the host is enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, I don't think a communion wafer has the recommended daily allowance of anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes, of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Mother Miriam looks down and is shocked to see Agnes white habit is spotted with blood, and more blood is drip the floor. She pulls out   Agnes' hand from her habit and shock; there is a bleeding hole in the middle of her palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm being punished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quickly leads Agnes out of the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It started this morning and I can't get it to stop.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Back in the present, as before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you take her to a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was healed by the following morning and she started eating again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had a... a hole in the palm of her hand! She could have bled to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she didn't... did she. If anyone had seen what I'd seen she'd be public property... newspapermen, psychiatrists, ridicule. She doesn't deserve that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're thinking, she's a hysteric pure and simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not simple, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it. Clean through the palm of her hand. Do you think hysteria could do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's being doing it for centuries. She's not unique, she's just another victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's victim. That's her innocence. She belongs to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I intend to take her away from Him. That's what you're afraid of isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha walks out. Mother Miriam yanks the padlock out of door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I am.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: All the Sisters are present. Mother Miriam leads the chan Latin and the   rest of the nuns respond at intervals. Ag happy. Their singing continues over, until the end of sce

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Martha and Larry are at the top of steps. He hands her an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are. Don't let anyone know where you got them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing him) Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Agnes is happily swinging on a long swing attached to a t

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The Sisters go about their tasks. Then all together they to a corner of the room which is laid out with burning ca make their devotions.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Agnes is confessing to a rather disinterested Father Martineau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last Tuesday, I didn't eat all of my lima beans... hid them under my spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) I thought... thoughts... about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up, I can hardly hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very loudly) I thought ugly thoughts about Sister Marguerite.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha is leafing through a sheaf of police photographs o the sheets and the waste-paper basket. She puts the photos aside and puf thoughtfully on a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Agnes is milking the cow. She pours the milk into a large churn. (The singing finishes at this point).

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The same four are in a meeting. This time they are all sitting except for Lyon who is standing by the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell me why the hell this is taking so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look there are a lot of unanswered questions here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha, your job is to diagnose, not to heal and play detective. Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know my job. Don't tell me my job Lyon. My duty as a doctor is to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha, you have to make a decision on her sanity as quickly as possible and not interfere with due process of law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no, excuse me Eve. As quickly as I see fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The longer you take to make a decision, the more difficult it will be for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bishop is breathing down our necks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the sooner she goes to prison, the better off she'll be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) ???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this. I don't bloody believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the bishop will be very upset about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fighting for this woman's life, not some bloody bishop.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It is a strange place; all the crosses are identical and simple. Martha is standing. Agnes is kneeling in front of a cross marked with the name "Soeur Marie Paul" and the dates she was born, consecrate and died. Agnes places some winter flowers on the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You liked Sister Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was kind to me. She told me I was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crouching down) What else did she tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said all of God's angels would want to sleep beside me if they could. I liked that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes makes the sign of the cross, they both stand and st to move off. AGNES (Cont.) She lived here for almost seventy years. Every day she'd ring the bell, wake us up, call us to God. She took me to my secret place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that?... I promise I won't tell, would you take me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Agnes takes her.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha and Agnes enter the bell-tower. Agnes leads the wa the steep wooden steps. Martha becomes breathless almost immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Paul was in her eighties?   Did she climb up here often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, only when she felt like it. She brought me up here last winter and the next day she died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (halting, out of breath) No wonder... wait... Agnes... Agnes how do you feel about babies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they frighten me, I'm afraid I'll drop them. They have a soft spot on their heads and if you drop them so they land on their heads they become stupid. I was dropped on my head, that's why I don't understand things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (climbing again) Numbers... you can spend your whole life counting and never reach the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her) I don't understand them either. Do you suppose I was dropped on my head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not. It's a terrible thing to be dropped on your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got to give up smoking. Agnes ... wait a minute... Agnes slow down.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Agnes climbs up through the trapdoor to the bell platform

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said you could see the whole world from up here. But it looks much better far away than it looks close up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha arrives exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes lies down under the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sometimes I get under here... it makes a wonderful sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to sing in a beautiful voice and the sound rin in the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if the bell rings and you're under there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's even more wonderful then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sings a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like hiding from my mother when I was a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no place as wonderful as this. Agnes... have you ever thought of leaving the convent for something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There is nothing else. Just being here at night helps me sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have trouble sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get headaches. Mommy did too... oh, but she wasn't stupid. She knew things that nobody else knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knew what was going to happen to me. That's why she hid me away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise I won't laugh. Who told her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angel, when she was having one of her headaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your mother see angels often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe she really saw them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I can never tell her that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd get angry. Martha moves round close to Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Agnes, did you love your mother?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Did you ever want to be a mother yourself?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I could never be a mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Well I don't think I'm old enough and besides I don't want to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Because I don't want one.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: If you did want one, how'd you go about getting one?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: From someone who didn't want to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Like you?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (suddenly frustrated) No, not like me!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: How would that person get one if they didn't want one?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (jumping to her feet) A mistake...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Agnes, how did your mother get you?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: A mistake... it was a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is that what she said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very upset) If you're trying to get me to say that she was a bad woman and hated me and didn't want me but that's not true, she was a good woman, a saint... (distorted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, I don't believe you know nothing about sex...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it if I'm stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that you don't remember getting pregnant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that you don't believe you carried a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything... I don't have children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha puts her arm out to Agnes who slaps it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me like that! You don't touch me like that, I know what you want from me, you want to take God away. You should be ashamed, they should lock you up people like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes disappears down through the trapdoor. Martha throws cigarette away.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam is comforting a tearful Agnes. She sees Mar coming across   the courtyard and pushes Agnes gently awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hate us don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuns... you hate nuns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate ignorance and stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Catholic Church...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't said anything against the the Catholic Church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catholicism is not on trial here. I want you to deal with Agnes without any religious prejudice or you turn this case over to someone else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you tell me to run my affairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam starts to walk away, Martha angrily follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my affair too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you think I'm in a position to be pressured...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only interested...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...    or bullied or what ever you're doing. Who    the hell do you think you are? You go    around here expecting applause for the    way you treated this child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha and Mother Miriam are climbing the stairs. They pa briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she has a right to know that there's a world out there filled with people who don't believe in God... (Mother Miriams walks on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and aren't any worse off than you Mother. People who've gone through their entire lives without bending their knees once, to anybody. And people who fall in love and have babies and occas- sionally are very happy. She has a right to know that. But you and your... your order and your Church have kept her ignorant... They reach Mother Miriam's study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ???     (distorted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ??? (distorted) ... virginity, right Mother? Poverty, chastity and ignorance is what you live by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a virgin, Doctor. I was married for twenty three years, two daughters. I even have grandchildren... surprised? It might please you to know that I was a failure as a wife and mother. My children won't even see me any more, that's their revenge. I think they tell their friends that I've passed on. And don't tell me I'm making up for past mistakes Doctor Freud. (she sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then help her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're shielding her. Let her face the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good would it do. No matter what you decide it's either the... the prison or the nut house and the differences between them are pretty thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aquittal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Innocence. Legal innocence. I know the judge would be happy for any reason to throw this case out of court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause. The tension between them dissolves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what do you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha holds her hand.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Same place, but a little later. Martha is smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When would Agnes have conceived the child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, some time in January.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember anything unusual happening at the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earthquakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitors to the convent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a... a diary or a day book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take at look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam moves to her desk and opens the day book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the child full term?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads through the book) Oh, Dear God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sheets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dear God, I should have guessed...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: In flashback: the sisters are sitting around the table at dinner. SISTER GENEVIEVE, the other novice is serving the Miriam folds up a linen    towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I should have suspected something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In flashback, Mother Miriam addresses Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Marguerite says you have been sleeping on a bare mattress Sister. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the medieval days the nuns and monks would sleep in their own coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Marguerite gives a snort of derision. Mother Miria glances sharply at her, then turns back to Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not in the Middle Ages, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It made them holy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It made them uncomfortable. And if they didn't sleep well I'm certain the next day they were cranky as mules. Sister where are your sheets? (no answer) Do you really believe that sleeping on a bare mattress is the equivalent of sleeping in a coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tell me. Where are your sheets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I burnt them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long pause) They were stained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times have I burned into your thick skull and the thick skull of your fellow novice, that menstruation is a perfectly natural process and nothing to be ashamed of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it! AGNES and GENEVIEVE It is a perfectly natural process and nothing to be ashamed of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mean it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two girls start to repeat it but Agnes starts to cry Genevieve falters into silence. Mother Miriam goes on more kindly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few years ago one of the Sisters came to me in tears, asking for comfort, comfort because she was too old to have any children. Not that she wanted to, but once a month she had been reminded of that possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that... it's not that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my time of month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should you see a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know what happened Mother, I woke up... there was blood on the sheets, but I don't know what happened. (starts to weep) I don't know what I did wrong, I don't know and I should be punished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the beginning, the night of the conception. That's why she burnt the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Still in flashback, Mother Miriam enters the room where

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: PAUL lies dying. Father Martineau is there and many of th nuns singing hymns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twenty third of January. On that night one of our elder nuns passed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I don't remember where Agnes was. I was needed in the sick room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Martineau annoints the old woman. Then Agnes quiet slips in   unobserved. Sister Paul rallies for a moment, a single silent word to her. The smile slips from Agnes' face. Then Siste Paul lies back and dies.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha and the MONSIGNOR are walking through the church talking. He is quite young and has a rather abrasive mann (beginning missed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you're probably right about that. It certainly can't help Sister Agnes to have this investigation continued for any length of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you call it an investigation? I never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother was a resident of Saint Catherines home before you moved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this have to do with..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you had a sister who died in the convent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still go to church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business is it of yours..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we just wonder if you can be very objective about this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Father, ah... just because I don't subscribe to the... to the beliefs you subscribe to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (halting) But what you believe makes no difference to us whatsoever Doctor. But it does make all the difference to Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Are you expecting me to..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well somone's got to suffer for this Doctor. You've got to be merciful and quick. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha stares at him as he walks away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A single shot of the back of the convent and the belltowe The bell is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam is ringing the bell and it takes quite a considerable effort.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Agnes has a wheelbarrow full of straw and manure. She dum it on a pile.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha is watching Agnes milking a cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, I'm here because I want to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're troubled... aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you keep reminding me. If you go away then I'll forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's unhappy, you're unhappy aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer me!    You never answer me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only you think    you're lucky because you didn't have    a mother who said things to you and did    things to you that maybe weren't always    nice but that was because of me, because    I was bad, not her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes carries the milk pail round to the churn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I breathed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes falls to her knees. Martha moves round and kneels i front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes. What did your mother do to you? (no answer) If you can't answer me, just shake your head yes or no. Did... did she hit you? (Anges shakes her head: no) Did she make you do something you didn't want to? (yes) Did it make you feel uncomfortable to do it? (yes) Did it embarrass you? (yes) Did it... did it hurt you? (yes) What did she make you you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You can tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: She's dead isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: She can't hurt you any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: She watches... she listens.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Agnes, I don't believe that. Tell me. I'll protect you from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... makes me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: ... take off my clothes and then... she makes fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: She tells you you're ugly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: And that you're stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: That you're a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: She says my whole body's a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Because she says if I don't watch out I'll have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: How does she know that?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Her headaches.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: And then...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: She touches me down there with a cigarette. (Martha gasps) Please Mommy, don't touch me like that any more. I'll be good, I won't be a baby any more.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Agnes, oh Agnes, Agnes I want you to do something. I want you to pretend that I'm your mother. Oh yes, only this time I want you to tell me what you're feeling, alright?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Please!    I want to help you. Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say? Of course you do. Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, you're stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you intelligent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more forcefully) Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) I'm not mistake, I'm here aren't I. How can I be a mistake if I'm really here. God doesn't make mistakes, you're a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is half shouting , half crying. Martha holds on to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Agnes, oh Agnes, it's alright, it's alright, it's alright, it's alright, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really love me or are you just saying that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as Mother Miriam does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as God loves you.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha is in there by herself smoking. The elderly nun appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been watching. We were fine 'till she came. She brought the devil here. (makes the sign of the cross) There was blood on her hand that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes? (the nun shakes her head) Who?     Mother Superior?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) ???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look into the convent records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the nun has gone, walking quickly away down the corri

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Sister (?) enters to find Martha going through a cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly guiltily) Oh, Good afternoon Sister, I... I'm looking for some biographical data on Sister Agnes, and Mother said I might find it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sister smiles, goes to another cabinet, extracts a fi and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sister nods and without a word leaves the room. Marth waits until she has gone, then opens the cabinet and pull another file. Glancing at the    door, she compares the t They both have the same surname Burchetti. The the door o Mother Miriam is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied to me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brandishing the files) Your niece!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't tell you because I didn't think it was important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it just makes you doubly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: responsible doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw Agnes until she set foot in this convent. My sister ran away from home. We lost touch with her. And when my husband died and I came here, she wrote to me and asked me if I would take care of Agnes in case anything happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Agnes' father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam turns out of the room. Martha goes after he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could have been any one of a dozen men from what my sister told me.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Continuing, just outside the record room. MOTHER MIRIAM (Cont.) She was afraid that Agnes would follow in her footsteps. She did everything she could to prevent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like keeping her home from school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listening to angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drank too much. That's what killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what she did to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I care to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She molested her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is more here than meets the eye isn't there? Lots of dirty little secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Oh God, if only I'd known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you? You knew she was keeping her home from school. You knew she was an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that after the fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you do anything to stop her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I didn't know... (she leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Larry is interviewing a young PROSTITUTE in French. Marth appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry there's got to be something missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you the pictures Marty, what else do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something they... that they overlooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You think that the girl is innocent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to be crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry pulls out a pack of cigarettes, gives one to Martha to the prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, you've seen the reports. It's a cut and dried case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's something that's not in the report that should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too involved Marty. (lights her cigarette) Jesus look at you. Why don't you turn this case over to someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry lights his own cigarette and comes over to Martha. LARRY (Cont.) I'll ask around, see what I come up with. In the meantime you go home and get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (she leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her) If I find anything I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Martha takes off her coat, moves across the room turning lights. She flicks the answerphone on. Her cat meows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Marty, it's Helen. Mrs Davenport called and was very upset that you'd missed her appointment. She wants you to call her at home, oh and a couple of reporters have been trying to get a hold of you about Sister Agnes. They seem persistent and they may try to reach you at home. I didn't give them number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some whirs and beeps. Martha goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (French accent) Hallo, Doctor Livingston. My name is (?). I'm doing a Sunday article on Sister Agnes for the Gazette. I would appreciate it if you would give me a phone call on 942-2424.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More beeps and whirs. Martha starts to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Marty, it's me. Listen I just talked with Detective Crawley who was at the convent. She said that there was one thing that bothered her that didn't make it into the report. The waste paper basket. The one in Agnes' room. (Martha freezes in the middle of lighting up) None of the other nuns had one. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha rushes over to the answerphone and rewinds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... her that didn't make it into the report. The waste paper basket. The one in Agnes' room. None of the other nuns had one. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha looks thoughtful and flicks off the desk lamp.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Father Martineau is saying Mass. All the sisters are ther singing together.      Father Martineau places the host i sconce, incences it and raises it up. Close on individual nuns at prayer including Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam is kneeling in the doorway of the barn, pra when Martha    enters. Mother Miriam pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotten the court's permission to hypnotise her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam makes the sign of the cross and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my permission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like yours too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam grabs a bucket and moves across the barn. Martha follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't deny it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman's health is at stake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her spiritual health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn about her spiritual health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Miriam starts shovelling grain into the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentence her and be done with it, that's what you're saying and I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am saying (distorted) a beautifully simple woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unhappy woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's happy with us and she could go on being happy if she was left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you call the police in the first place Mother, huh? MARTHA (cont.) Why didn't you just throw the baby into the incinerator and be done with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I am a moral person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catholic Church doesn't have a corner on morality...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about the Catholic Church...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell has the Catholic Church got to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we done to hurt you? And don't deny it, I can smell an ex-Catholic a mile away. What did we do? Burn a few heretics, sell some indulgences? That was in the days when the Church was a ruling body. We let governments do those things today. So what did we do to you eh? You wanted to neck in the back seat of a car when you were fifteen and you couldn't because it was a sin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time it is Martha who walks away and Mother Miriam w follows her. MOTHER MIRIAM (Cont.) So instead of questioning that one rule...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (halting) It wasn't sex. It was a lot of things, but it wasn't sex. You know when I was in the first grade my best friend was run over on the way to school, you know what the nun said? She died because she hadn't said her morning prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid woman... and that's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all? That's enough!   She was a beautiful little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what has that to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't. I wasn't. She was the pretty one. She died, why not me? I never said my morning prayers. And I was ugly, I was scrawny, I had buck teeth and freckles all over my face, do you know what the nun called me, Sister Mary Clitus, called me Polkadot Livingston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you left the Church because you had freckles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, because I... yeah, yeah I left the Church cause I had freckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both cannot help laughing at this absurdity.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A couple of nuns walk across the courtyard. Another is meditating alone. On a bench a nun kisses a dove and lets it fly away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It is out the back of the convent near the belltower. Mot Miriam and Martha are sitting there talking. Martha is smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
